dc:title: The accumulation of genetic variation in a parthenogenetic snail.
dc:creator: Stoddart J.
dc:description: Variation present in 13 populations of an apomictic freshwater prosobranch, Thiara balonnensis, was assessed electrophoretically. With one exception, each population contained a single unique clone. The pattern of variation was postulated to result from the evolution of new clones by mutation and the loss of alleles after geographic separation. The extent of the variation present in this species suggests that in favorable environments, apomictic species may persist and accumulate variation without recombination or segregation.-from Author

dc:title: Clonal diversity and population structure in a reef-building coral, Acropora cervicornis. Self-recognition analysis and demographic interpretation.
dc:creator: Neigel J.
dc:description: When branches of Acropora cervicornis come into contact, within several months the tissues and calcareous matrix exhibit either an acceptance or rejection response. These responses accurately distinguish clonemates (the products of asexual fragmentation of colonies) from non-clonemates (the products of sexual recruitments) . This self-recognition bioassay was used to analyze the clonal structure and diversity in A. cervicornis populations in Discovery Bay, Jamaica, and Tague Bay, St. Croix, US Virgin Islands. The Discovery Bay population has a significantly greater microgeographic clonal diversity that is reflected in a much higher Neighbor Index, the proportion of rejection responses in contacts among adjacent colonies. In Tague Bay, spatial maps of A. cervicornis clones show that clones are variable in size (from a single colony to assemblages up to 10 m or more in diameter), and are distributed in discrete patches. A computer model was used to simulate the development of clonal population structure from simple demographic processes. This indicated that the relatively low diversity of clones apparent in the Tague Bay population is expected when the input of new clones into the population by sexual recruitment is extemely low. Occasions of catastrophic mortality and subsequent recovery of A. cervicornis populations may be major determinants of clonal diversity and population structure, especially when the rate of sexual recruitment is relatively low.-from Authors

dc:title: Hybrid origin of polyploidy in freshwater snails of the genus Bulinus ( Mollusca: Planorbidae).
dc:creator: Goldman M.
dc:description: G-banded karyotypes of the diploid freshwater snail, Bulinus tropicus, and of the tetraploid, B. truncatus, were studied in order to determine whether the tetraploid had arisen through hybridization of karyotypically distinct taxa or through simple doubling of the genome, and to infer cytological characteristics of the diploid taxa involved in the origin of the tetraploid.-from Authors

dc:title: Convergence of ecological processes between independently evolved competitive dominants: a tunicate- mussel comparison.
dc:creator: Paine R.
dc:description: Comparison between the tunicate Pyura praeputialis and a mussel, Mytilus californianus, suggests that large body size, relatively rapid growth, some mechanism insuring group morphological continuity, susceptibility to disturbance, and larval recruitment onto the adult proper are ecological features held in common. A diverse associated community may benefit these matrix-forming species by reducing overgrowths or even eliminating large-bodied potential competitors. Such features can be identified in a Cretaceous bivalve and a Permian brachiopod, species which were likely to have been matrix-forming community dominants themselves.-from Authors

dc:title: A coadapted trophic niche in two species of Crustaceae ( Isopoda): Asellus aquaticus (L.) and Proasellus coxalis Dolff.
dc:creator: Rossi L.
dc:description: Asellus aquaticus and Proasellus coxalis from populations living sympatrically have a potential trophic niche much more differentiated than do the populations living allopatrically. In particular, progeny of the 2 species when sympatric showed similar survival on only 25% of tested fungal resources. The 2 species when sympatric are specialized for microfungi not very common in nature; more common microfungi are used without distinction by individuals of both species. The exclusiveness of each resource for the sympatric populations increases inversely with the abundance in nature of the resource itself. In P. coxalis, the number of survivors eating a particular fungus increases in the F1 and F2 vs. parental generations. Results emphasize a possible effect of co-occurrence on character displacement and support the hypothesis of coevolutionary trophic partitioning between the species.-from Authors

dc:title: Patterns and levels of genetic variation in Great Basin bristlecone pine, Pinus longaeva.
dc:creator: Hiebert R.D.
dc:description: Low interpopulation variation and the high intrapopulation variation, along with paleoecological data, argue for the continuity of P. longaeva throughout much of the Great Basin during the last full glacial. The maintenance of high levels of variation from that time until the present are a result of several factors which appear to include: 1) high outcrossing rates; 2) maintenance of large population sizes; 3) production of large numbers of seeds; 4) microhabitat adaption in a spatially and temporally heterogeneous environment. -from Authors

dc:title: Phylogenetic inference from restriction endonuclease cleavage site maps with particular reference to the evolution of humans and the apes.
dc:creator: Templeton A.R.
dc:description: The estimation procedure utilizes a compatibility analysis between enzyme data sets of the most parsimonious trees constructed from the restriction enzyme. Next, a non-parametric test is given for comparing alternative phylogenies. A 2nd non-parametric test is developed for testing the molecular clock hypothesis. To illustrate the power of these procedures, data derived from the mitochondrial DNA and globin DNA of man and the apes are analyzed. Although previous analyses of these data led to the speculation that 10 times more information would be required to resolve the evolutionary relationships between man with chimps and gorillas, this algorithm resolved these relationships at the 5% level of significance. The molecular clock hypothesis was rejected at the 1% level. The implications of this phylogenetic inference when coupled with other types of data lead to the conclusion that knuckle-walking - not bipedalism - is the evolutionary novelty in mode of locomotion in the primates and that many other hominid features are primitive whereas their African ape counterparts are derived.-from Author

dc:title: A steep cline in Pinus muricata ( bishop pine, California).
dc:creator: Millar C.I.
dc:description: Two northern California bishop pine populations differing in stomatal form, monoterpene composition, flowering time, and allozyme frequency are separated by a cline of <3 km width. Allelic frequencies at a marker allozyme locus in standing trees changed from an average of 0.97 north of the cline to 0.23 south of the cline. Differences in allelic frequencies between mature trees and embryos are attributed to long distance pollen flow across the cline. Genetic, ecological, and paleontological evidence suggests that the cline resulted from recent contact of formerly isolated populations. -from Author

dc:title: High levels of phenotypic variability of metal and temperature tolerance in Paramecium.
dc:creator: Nyberg D.
dc:description: Tolerance to 8 metals and high temperature was measured for 26 stocks of P. primaurelia and 10 stocks of P. triaurelia. Among the P. primaurelia stocks, which had been collected at 14 locations, there were significant differences in tolerance to Cu, Co, Hg, Zn, Ni, Cr and Cd (listed in decreasing order based on the magnitude of the difference between the most resistant and most sensitive stocks). Among the P. triaurelia stocks, from 7 locations, there were significant differences in tolerance to Cu, Hg, Cr, Co and Cd. The large, and consistent between species, among-locations variance in tolerance to Cu and Hg is consistent with an adaptive interpretation of tolerances. Because of their greater variability of tolerance, Cu and Hg probably have been of selective importance more frequently than the other metals. -from Authors

dc:title: Grasshopper mandibles and the niche variation hypothesis.
dc:creator: Patterson B.D.
dc:description: A test of the hypothesis that phenotypic variation within populations is correlated with niche width is made in an attempt to assess the importance of environmental grain to the evolution of niche width in sexual species. Patterns of mandibular morphology in species of Acrididae are compared to independently derived estimates of trophic niche width. No support for the niche variation hypothesis (or its corollary, the niche polymorphism hypothesis) is found in the variability of single populations of grasshoppers. -from Author

dc:title: Host range evolution. The shift from native legume hosts to alfalfa by the butterfly, Colias philodice eriphyle ( Medicago sativa).
dc:creator: Tabashnik B.E.
dc:description: Colias philodice eriphyle has pest populations which feed in the field on alfalfa Medicago sativa and non-pest populations which feed on several legumes, but not on alfalfa. Non-pest females laid a substantial fraction of their eggs on alfalfa in preference tests and non-pest larvae were able to grow on alfalfa without a severe disadvantage relative to their growth on native hosts. Genetic changes in host use characters would thus not be required for a shift to alfalfa. Oviposition choice tests showed no differences between pest and non-pest females. On alfalfa, pest larvae grew better than non-pest larvae; but on native hosts, non-pest larvae grew better than pest larvae. Results suggest that pest C. p. eriphyle have improved their ability to grow on alfalfa, while losing some of their ability to grow on native hosts. Shifts to closely related plant species are not likely to lead to rapid divergence. -from Author

dc:title: Extensive genetic variation in mitochondrial DNA's among geographic populations of the deer mouse, Peromyscus maniculatus.
dc:creator: Lansman R.A.
dc:description: Data support the hypothesis that mammalian mtDNA evolves primarily by the accumulation of single base substitutions which occur in most of the coding regions of the genome. The data clearly distinguish five major genetic assemblages within P. maniculatus, as well as extensive clonal diversity within each of those assemblages. -from Authors

dc:title: Determinants of multiple host use by a phytophagous insect population.
dc:creator: Singer M.C.
dc:description: The following question was asked of an oligophagous butterfly population: how does the use of several hosts arise from the behavior of individual insects? There are at least 3 mechanisms: 1) Some individuals behave as generalists themselves, and have almost equal likelihoods of depositing their eggs on different host species. 2) The population contains insects with different distinct preferences. This variation in preference affects variation in host use. 3) One of the most highly preferred hosts is sufficiently rare and localized that most insects which do prefer it search without finding it until other, less preferred hosts become acceptable. They then oviposit on these secondarily preferred species. The degree of host specialization (specificity) is a continuous variable in this population. While some butterflies show 'neutral' preference and fail to discriminate between potential host species, others are just as host-specific as individuals in strictly monophagous populations (of the same species). In such monophagous populations there is no variation of preference rank order and no undiscriminating insects (with 'neutral' preference) have been found. In consequence, the distribution and abundance of potential hosts does not usually affect breadth of host use by the population. -from Author

dc:title: Macrogeographic variation in litter size in Antechinus ( Marsupialia: Dasyuridae).
dc:creator: Cockburn A.
dc:description: Litter size in the dasyurid marsupial genus Antechinus is highly correlated with nipple number, which shows macrogeographic variation between populations of the 3 species with extensive ranges in eastern Australia. Males die after their first attempt at reproduction, and females produce 1-2 litters in their lifetime. Nipple number is highest at high elevations in SE Australia, and lowest at low latitudes and on the exposed capes and promontories in SE Australia. The relationship between litter size and adult survival is equivocal, and predation pressure is unlikely to vary consistently across gradients of litter size. There appears to be a relationship between seasonality and litter size. Antechinus may produce broods which correspond to the number of young they can nourish. -from Authors

dc:title: Testing the female mimicry hypothesis of delayed plumage maturation: a comment on Procter-Gray and Holmes.
dc:creator: Rohwer S.
dc:description: Discusses tests which could refute the hypothesis that female mimicry facilitates the establishment of female-worthy territories by young males, and evaluates the conclusions of Procter-Gray and Holmes (Evolution, 35, 1981, pp 742-751) in light of these tests and other issues. -from Author

dc:title: Genetic variability within and among populations of the black- tailed prairie dog ( Cynomys ludovicianus New Mexico).
dc:creator: Chesser R.K.
dc:description: In eastern New Mexico, significant genetic differentiation was found for Cynomys ludovicianus from populations in close proximity (5-15 km) as well as for those from distant parts of their range. The degree of local differentiation was greater than that among regions separated by major geographical barriers. Significant heterogeneity of allele frequencies was found for prairie dogs from different wards (portions of a population separated by unsuitable habitat) within a population, as well as for those from different coteries (harem groups) within the wards. The social behavior of prairie dogs has resulted in genetic differentiation over very small distances and rapid inbreeding and genetic drift within the social groups. -from Author

dc:title: Competition between high and low mutating strains of Escherichia coli.
dc:creator: Chao L.
dc:description: Previous studies have shown that strains of E. coli with high mutation rates have a marked advantage in competition with wild- type strains. Those studies, however, failed to discriminate between the hypotheses that the mutator bacteria acquired an advantage by evolving faster, on the one hand, or that they had an intrinsic competitive advantage, on the other. The present investigation supports the first hypothesis.-from Authors

dc:title: Resource partitioning among genotypes of Drosophila pseudoobscura.
dc:creator: Taylor C.E.
dc:description: The model laboratory test consisted of D. pseudoobscura larvae in small petri dishes containing one type of medium on one side and another type of medium on the other. There were genotype X environment interactions for all component of fitness studied; 2) survivorship was density-independent; 3) there was habitat choice, in that strains tended to prefer the media on which they developed faster; and 4) when individuals or different strains were placed together there was a small tendency for them to occupy the different microhabits for resource partitioning among genotypes. There was an increase in overall fitness when environmental heterogeneity is introduced.-from Authors

dc:title: Gene diversity and genetic structure in a narrow endemic, Torrey pine ( Pinus torreyana Parry ex Carr) ( San Diego, Santa Rosa Island, California).
dc:creator: Ledig F.T.
dc:description: This California endemic occurs in only 2 populations, one on the coast at San Diego and one 280km NW on Santa Rosa Island. Populations number only c.7000 and 2000 individuals, respectively. Each population is composed of identical homozygous genotypes at 59 isozyme loci. The island population is fixed for alternate alleles to those in the coastal population at two of the 59 loci. Results agree with other lines of evidence that suggest Torrey pine is characterized by minor differences between relatively uniform populations. Drift is the most likely explanation for lack of variability in Torrey pine. The founder effect may have operated during colonization of Santa Rosa Island c.18 000 BP.-from Authors

dc:title: The Kluge-Kerfoot phenomenon - a statistical artifact.
dc:creator: Rohlf F.J.
dc:description: Since the 1973 paper by Kluge and Kerfoot, many studies have reported a statistically significant positive correlation between indices of the average amount of variability found within a local population for a character and the amount of differentiation among population means for that character. The statistics used have been based on coefficients of variation in order to correct for the effects of differences in scale in different characters and in different populations. Evolutionary theory has been called upon in a number of these papers to help explain this positive association (the 'Kluge-Kerfoot phenomenon'). Data sets which had been used previously were reanalyzed. There was an inverse (and usually hyperbolic) relationship between the mean of a character and both its within- and its among-population coefficients of variation. One thus expects these latter 2 variables to be correlated since they are both correlated with the same variable. The inverse relationships found in the various data sets can be explained on the basis of one or more of the following: the effect due to having a mixture of different kinds of variables in a single study, the effect of grouping data into relatively coarse classes, the effect of measurement error, or the effect of using variables that have a discrete distribution. While there may actually be a correlation between the levels within- and among-population variability, previous studies do not provide adequate data to allow an investigation of such a relationship.-from Authors

dc:title: Genetic and environmental components of clutch size variance in a wild population of lesser snow geese ( Anser caerulescens caerulescens).
dc:creator: Findlay C.S.
dc:description: Proximate environmental influences include female age, timing of laying and nutrient reserve status. Analysis of the heritability of clutch size indicates that a significant proportion of clutch size variance arises from additive gene effects. Quantitative assessment of the variance contribution from additive effects is, however, confounded by the effects of potential genotype-environment correlations, genotype-environment interactions, and assortative mating by correlated characters. Laboratory results may not adequately represent the genetic architecture of large outbred populations in their natural environments.-from Authors

dc:title: Male fertility and anisoplethic population structure in tristylous Pontedera cordata ( Pontederiaceae).
dc:creator: Barrett S.C.H.
dc:description: Average frequencies of the long-, mid- and short-styled morphs in a survey of 74 populations are 0.255, 0.346 and 0.399, respectively. Populations are heterogeneous for morph frequency and 76.8% of the 69 trimorphic populations displayed significant anisoplethy. Populations most frequently exhibit a predominance of the short-styled morph and a deficiency of the long-styled morph, irrespective of locality, habitat type or population size. The pattern is also evident at a spatial scale of 20 m2 in two linear roadside ditch populations in North Carolina. A computer simulation model suggests that known differences in pollen production at mid-level anthers of the long- and short-styled morphs could account for the observed anisoplethic population structure in P. cordata as a result of mating asymmetries among the morphs. Variation in pollen production between the mid-level anthers of the long- and short-styled morphs possibly arises because of differences in floral development between the forms and may have no direct adaptive value.-from Authors

dc:title: Gene flow distances in natural populations of Tetraopes tetraophthalmus.
dc:creator: McCauley D.E.
dc:description: Movement patterns of reproducing adults and information on survivorship and fertility patterns during the reproductive/dispersal period of the milkweed beetle are combined to provide estimates of the gene flow distance in 2 populations with contrasting habitat structure. Implications of results for micro-evolutionary processes are discussed. -from Author

dc:title: Molecular variation in insular endemic Drosophila species of the Macaronesian Archipelagos.
dc:creator: Gonzalez A.M.
dc:description: Drosophila guanche and D. madeirensis, have levels of molecular variation similar to those of species with much wider distribution ranges. Both species may be considered actual relicts of a primitive ancestor of the melanogaster and obscura groups.-from Authors

dc:title: Distribution of sexual and apomictic populations of Antennaria parlinii.
dc:creator: Bayer R.J.
dc:description: Populations of the dioecious composite Antennaria parlinii along a transect from West Virginia to NW Ohio are mostly sexual in the unglaciated SE region. In the glaciated region in NW Ohio, populations consist entirely or chiefly of pistillate clones. Near the terminal moraine of the Wisconsin glaciation, 2 populations contain a mixture of sexual, fully apomictic and facultatively apomictic clones. In general, where populations are closely spaced in varied habitats, sexual clones are most successful. Widely spaced populations are primarily or entirely apomictic, perhaps because of the colonizing ability of the apomicts. The presence of facultative apomicts suggests gradual evolution of obligate anomixis.-Authors

dc:title: Interspecific variation in the size of the nutrient investment made by male butterflies during copulation.
dc:creator: Rutowski R.L.
dc:description: Interspecific comparisons of lepidopteran mating behavior reveal that there is surprisingly little variation in the overall structure of mating behavior from species to species. This apparent lack of strong interspecific differences in behavior suggests minor differences between species in the intensity of sexual selection and therefore that the nutritional investments made by males during copulation are similar from species to species. This paper represents a preliminary effort to test this prediction by comparing the quantities of material passed by males on a per unit body weight basis for 10 species of butterflies that are common in the southern USA.-from Authors

dc:title: Intraspecific genetic variation and haplodiploidy, eusociality, and polygyny in the Hymenoptera.
dc:creator: Berkelhamer R.C.
dc:description: Mean heterozygosity values for 101 insect species were analyzed to test a series of hypotheses concerning the patterning of genetic variability within the Hymenoptera. The following conclusions are drawn. 1) 50 hymenopteran species have significantly lower H values than do 51 diplodiploid non-hymenopterans. 2) Among Hymenoptera, primitively eusocial species are less genetically variable than either solitary or advanced eusocial species. The latter 2 groups do not differ. 3) Among ants studied, polygynous and monogynous species have similar levels of genetic variability.-from Author

dc:title: A cost of reproduction in a terrestrial isopod.
dc:creator: Brody M.S.
dc:description: The hypothesis that small body size can decrease the probability of surviving was tested on a terrestrial isopod. Females were subjected to regimes of desiccation and lethal low temperatures (important, naturally occuring physical environmental stresses). Larger females usually survived these stresses when smaller females did not. During periods of reduced food availability females reproduced rather than grow, therefore remaining smaller and reducing their probability of survival, and therefore also reducing their probability of future reproduction. This constitutes a measurable cost of reproduction.-from Authors English

dc:title: Clonal diversity and evolutionary dynamics in a diploid breeding complex of unisexual fishes ( Poecilia).
dc:creator: Turner B.J.
dc:description: A unisexual-bisexual 'breeding complex' of viviparous poeciliid fishes exists in the Rio Soto la Marina Basin in NE Mexico. The complex consists of an indigenous bisexual 'host' species, Poecilia 'mexicana' (possibly distinct on the specific or subspecific level from nominally conspecific populations elsewhere in Mexico), a diploid all-female gynogen, P. formosa (ultimately of exogenous origin), and triploid all-female gynogens that result from fertilization of diploid P. formosa ova by host sperm. As assessed by allozyme technique, the host population has average levels of heterozygosity, but is highly differentiated geographically. The level of differentiation, even among samples collected along a single tributary, is much higher than is encountered in shortfin mollies in other drainages, and is at the upper limit of the known variation of conspecific fish populations in a single drainage. Allozyme variability is low in the diploid unisexual. In contrast, variability among the triploids was rather high.-from Authors Poecilia formosa Poecilia mexicana Rio Soto la Marina Basin Mexico. English

dc:title: Genetic and environmental determinants of wing polymorphism in the waterstrider Limnoporus canaliculatus.
dc:creator: Zera A.J.
dc:description: There was a strong genetic component to morph determination, but results were inconsistent with a single-locus, two-allele mode of inheritance. Photoperiod strongly influenced morph determination, with a higher proportion of long-winged morphs being produced in the short-decreasing photoperiod treatment. A photoperiod-dependent morph X sex association was also observed.-from Authors

dc:title: Contrasting gene flow patterns and genetic subdivision in adjacent populations of Cucumis sativus ( Cucurbitaceae).
dc:creator: Handel S.N.
dc:description: A test of the similarity of gene migration patterns between adjacent field populations of cucumber was conducted by interplanting a block of plants with the dominant bitter gene in the center of each of two large plots of plants with the recessive allele for this marker. After natural pollination, mature fruits were mapped and then collected throughout both fields, and the seedling progeny scored for the presence of the bitter gene. The pattern of gene flow in both plots was very restricted, with most of the bitter pollen deposited within 2-3 m from the central bitter block. These and other results show that adjacent plant populations, even in homogeneous environments, can have different pollen flow dynamics, and that there can be a directional migration of alleles in a plant population without the influence of a selection pressure acting on one part of the population.-from Author

dc:title: Breeding system and habitat effects on fitness components in three neotropical Costus ( Zingiberaceae).
dc:creator: Schemske D.W.
dc:description: All species are self-compatible, and require a treefall gap for germination and establishment. Self-pollination resulted in lower seed output in all species; this difference was significant for Costus allenii and C. laevis. Seedling growth of selfed, outcrossed and naturally-pollinated Costus allenii, C. laevis and C. guanaiensis in sun and shade habitats in the greenhouse was unaffected by breeding system, but significantly affected by habitat, with reduced growth in shade. Selfed progeny had the lowest biomass in all treatments, with inbreeding depression for growth ranging from 8-25% compared to out-crossed performance. Reduced growth and greater variation in growth for selfed, as compared to out-crossed, progeny are consistent with the hypothesis that inbreeding depression in these species results from homozygosity of rare, deleterious alleles which are not expressed in the heterozygous state. Relative biomass production varied more between sun and shade habitats for selfed, than outcrossed or naturally-pollinated progeny, suggesting that increased homozygosity following inbreeding reduces genotypic versatility.-from Author

dc:title: Larval adaptations and patterns of brachiopod diversity in space and time.
dc:creator: Valentine J.W.
dc:description: While it is possible that the articulates have always been nonplanktotrophic, Paleozoic brachiopods had diversity patterns suggesting that they possessed both planktotrophic and nonplanktotrophic models; they dominated the skeletonized faunas in many tropical benthic communities. The planktotrophic lineages were possibly lost to extinction, mostly or entirely during the Permian-Triassic event. The failure of the articulate brachiopods to regain their former importance owes significantly to restrictions arising from their nonplanktotrophic developmental mode. -from Authors

dc:title: DNA/DNA hybridization studies of muroid rodents: symmetry and rates of molecular evolution.
dc:creator: Brownell E.
dc:description: The evolutionary relationships of 16 rodent species are examined with respect to DNA annealing data. Rodent single-copy CNA sequences diverge at a constant average rate, and this feature makes DNA hybridization measurements of systematic value. For example, the microtines (Microtus, Clethrionomys, Ondatra), are found to be more closely related to North American cricetines than to Mesocricetus, a representative of the Eurasian cricetines-a relationship that is ambiguous on the basis of morphological and fossil data. Deletions, duplications and translocations are especially apparent in the rodent (Mus) genome, although such events may not necessarily be detected on the protein level. Data are consistent with the observation that phenotypic lability often correlates with the incidence of genetic rearrangement, rather than with the stochastic accumulation of point mutations in single-copy DNA sequences.-from Author

dc:title: Unorthodoxies in the first formulation of natural selection.
dc:creator: Gould S.J.
dc:description: Reassesses the importance of an early essay on skin colour and natural selection by W.C.Wells (1757-1817) in which he advocated some of the 'unorthodox' views on evolution still causing contention in modern debate.-M.Barrett

dc:title: A population genetical study of the African mosquito Anopheles marshallii (Theobald).
dc:creator: Lambert D.M.
dc:description: Analysis revealed the existence of at least 4 genetically distinct species within the taxon. These morphologically cryptic species differ by a number of fixed arrangements on the sex chromosomes as well as the autosomes. Results are discussed while considering the likely morphological changes accompanying speciation in such a group as Anopheles mosquitoes where individuals appear, in general, not to use morphological characteristics in mate recognition.-from Author

dc:title: The genetic basis of differences in life-history traits among six populations of mosquitofish ( Gambusia affinis) that shared ancestors in 1905.
dc:creator: Stearns S.C.
dc:description: Documents the degree to which 6 populations of mosquitofish that shared common ancestors in 1905 had diverged by 1980. Two populations from Hawaii inhabited reservoirs whose water level did not vary; 4 populations from Maui inhabited reservoirs whose water level fluctuated dramatically on periods ranging from days to seasons. Island effects (effects of stable vs. fluctuating water levels) were significant for male and female age and length at maturity and for offspring weight. Females from stable reservoirs were larger and younger at maturity and had smaller offspring than females from fluctuating reservoirs. Males from stable reservoirs were smaller and younger at maturity than males from fluctuating reservoirs. Stock effects (effects associated with particular reservoirs) were significant for male and female age and length at maturity and growth rates, for the slope of the fecundity-length relation, and for offspring weights. The only significant correlation among stock means was between longevity and length at maturity. Results do not fit neatly into any scheme that dichotomizes life-histories into a group of early-maturing, highly fecund organisms that have short lives and small young, and late-maturing, long-lived organisms that have a few large young. Correlations between measures of water level fluctuations in the reservoirs and the life-history traits of the fish whose parents had lived in those reservoirs were significant and consistent with field observations of the impact of fluctuations on mortality rates. - from Author

dc:title: A comparison of theoretical and electrophoretic assessments of genetic structure in populations of the house sparrow ( Passer domesticus).
dc:creator: Fleischer R.C.
dc:description: Electromorph frequencies at 4 loci show insignificant microgeographic differentiation among 5 farm colonies of house sparrows in eastern Kansas (average FST = .0076). Using estimates of interfarm dispersal and effective population size, a theoretical FST value is calculated from equations of the stepping stone model of genetic structure. The theoretical value (1.036) does not differ significantly from the mean FST estimated from electrophoretic data.-from Author

dc:title: Continental patterns of morphological variation in a South American sparrow.
dc:creator: Handford P.
dc:description: Geographic variation in bill, leg, foot and wing characters is described in rufous-collared sparrow Zonotrichia capensis which ranges from southern Mexico throughout all of South America. The sexes differ strongly in size yet their geographical variation in shape is virtually identical. There is no clear relationship of intrapopulation variability with latitude. Several characters show latitudinal clines (especially if only the Andean region is considered). The longest and (in terms of volume) the largest bills are found in the tropics; the shortest and smallest in Patagonia, a pattern which perhaps relates to mean food particle size. Longest wings are found in temperate high altitudes and at high latitudes, interpreted as a reflection of a migratory/nomadic habit.-from Author

dc:title: Variation in development patterns of larval anurans in temporary ponds: I. Persistent variation within a Hyla gratiosa population.
dc:creator: Travis J.
dc:description: Investigated the consistency and strength of variation in larval growth patterns among full-sib families of frogs from one breeding population of Hyla gratiosa in a temporary pond in North Carolina. Because growth rate is directly related to survivorship (through forces of mortality such as size-limited predators and desiccation) , variation among sibships in growth patterns will lead to differential survival among sibships. The level of such differential survival, however, will vary with the amount of variation in growth rate, this level apparently fluctuates from one season to the next, and even from one breeding bout to the next within a season. If larger size at metamorphosis of some sibships is to 'balance' their greater mortality through slower growth, there must be some seasons in which there is a decreased advantage to rapid development (perhaps through stable water levels and low predator densities) plus environmental conditions that cause slowly developing larvae to emerge larger, because there appears to be no consistent, ineluctable correlation of those traits.-from Author

dc:title: Genetic variation for host preference within and among populations of Drosophila tripunctata.
dc:creator: Jaenike J.
dc:description: Drosophila tripunctata is a polyphagous species that breeds in both mushrooms and fruits. Substantial genetic variation for host preference among strains was significant not only for strains from different geographic areas, but also for strains from a population in the Great Smoky Mountains. Variation within D. tripunctata may be a function of its niche breadth and thus maintained by natural selection.-from Authors

dc:title: Quantitative genetic response to environmental heterogeneity in Tribolium confusum.
dc:creator: Zirkle D.F.
dc:description: Estimates genetic variability for female pupa weight in a series of flour beetle populations subjected to either constant or variable environments. Evolutionary forces are shown to affect allele frequencies at loci that influence female pupa weight.-from Authors

dc:title: Pollen dispersal by hummingbirds and butterflies: a comparative study of two lowland tropical plants.
dc:creator: Webb C.J.
dc:description: Reports results of a comparative study of pollen flow for 2 early successional species in Costa Rica: Malvaviscus arboreus, a hummingbird-pollinated shrub or small tree, with hermaphrodite flowers; Cnidoscolus urens, a monoecious, butterfly-pollinated annual herb. M. arboreus was confined to margins and light gaps in the river forest; C. urens was found in a fallow rice field adjoining the river forest. Pollen dispersal was measured from a given plant at 2 or 3 different times, and actual number of plants which received pollen for the whole population was determined. The number of plants from which a given plant may receive pollen was also estimated, an estimate never made before. The effect of flower number on the amount of pollen removed was studied, as were the distance to which pollen is dispersed, and the number of plants to which pollen is donated. -from Authors

dc:title: Temperature effects on life history variation in Drosophila simulans.
dc:creator: Murphy P.A.
dc:description: Presents a half sib-full sib analysis of genetic and environmental components of several fitness indices for Drosophila simulans cultered at 4 environmental temperatures which ranged from 20-30oC. -from Author.

dc:title: Morphological variation in the neotropical salamander genus Bolitoglossa.
dc:creator: Alberch P.
dc:description: A series of traits involving the presence or absence of bones in the anterior region of the skull, in the tarsus, and in the toes was analyzed. Variation is definitively bounded, and traits observed as variants in a population of a given species are found fixed in other species (ie population polymorphisms parallel interspecific diversity). The patterns observed can largely be explained mainly as the products of heterochronic regulation of resilient developmental programs. It is plausible to view this as the kind of variation that provides the raw material in processes of evolutionary morphological diversification. Most importantly, the variation is clearly non-random and largely a reflection of the structure of the developmental program which imposes constraints on its expression. An understanding of ontogeny can thus allow us to make some predictions about phylogeny.-from Author

dc:title: The influence of Palaeozoic ovule and cupule morphologies on wind pollination.
dc:creator: Niklas K.J.
dc:description: The aerodynamic properties of various Paleozoic ovules appear to have been significant in directing wind-borne pollen or prepollen toward the salpinx or micropyle. Ovule models with roughened surfaces have a lower probability of direct pollination than morphologically comparable, but glabrous, models. Models of cupulate ovules with integumentary excrescences have complex particle impaction patterns. Excrescences reduce the number of direct spore/pollen impactions with micropyles.-from Author

dc:title: Pattern and chance in the structure of model and natural communities.
dc:creator: Case T.J.
dc:description: Reanalysis of data on the Galapagos finch fauna reveals a significant trend of bill size assortment in both the ground finches (Geospiza) and tree finches (Camarhynchus), ie size-dissimilar species sets are more common than expected. There was no evidence for size adjustment in either group, although available sample sizes (islands with complete size data) are so small that this lack of pattern is inconclusive. -from Authors

dc:title: The evolution of aposematic coloration in distasteful prey: an individual selection model.
dc:creator: Sillen-Tullberg B.
dc:description: Given the assumptions that the probability of being killed when siezed <1.0, and that a predator's avoidance reaction is improved with an increase in the degree of aposematic coloration, the model demonstrates that aposematic coloration can evolve by individual rather than kin selection. The likelihood that a mutation for aposematic coloration will be favored over one for cryptic coloration increases with 1) the initial probability of detection, 2) the relative payoff, as measured by a decrease in the number of seizures with an increase in the degree of aposematic coloration, and 3) a reduction in the number of seizures at a given probability of detection, as a result of an increase in the level of distastefulness. Kin selection is a more likely explanation for the evolution of aposematic coloration in a distasteful species than for distastefulness per se, but individual selection is a fully sufficient explanation for both distastefulness and aposematic coloration. -from Authors

dc:title: Multiple mating and female fitness in Drosophila pseudoobscura.
dc:creator: Turner M.E.
dc:description: Fitness of Drosophila pseudoobscura females allowed to mate over a 2 day period was compared with that of females given lifetime access to males. The females kept with males mated repeatedly. Overall fitness of the remated females under nutritional stress, the product of their longevities and productivities, remained severalfold that of females allowed to mate only for an initial 2 day period. The fitness advantage of remated females provides a powerful selective advantage for repeated mating which must reinforce the sexual selection favoring males who mate repeatedly, and it makes the evolution of multiple mating easier to understand. -from Authors

dc:title: Genetic variation and differentiation of remnant natural populations of the desert pupfish, Cyprinodon macularius.
dc:creator: Turner B.J.
dc:description: Six remnant natural populations of Cyprinodon macularius, a formerly broadly distributed Colorado Basin species, were surveyed for allozyme variation at the products of 38-39 structural gene loci. The samples included 4 populations from the Salton Sea area (including one from an adjacent relatively pristine natural desert spring habitat), one from the Sonoyta (Quitobaquito Springs), and one ultimately from near the delta of the Colorado River. Mean heterozygosity values are within the range reported by others for ecologically comparable Aphanius populations, and are not strikingly low. Eight loci display statistically significant differences in gene frequency. Differences are detectable among Salton Sea populations, and among all 3 geographic areas. The general pattern of the differentiation is temporally (and geographically) hierarchical, and is consistent with previous perceptions of the relationships of the populations based on morphology. The overall level of differentiation is low. The effect of geographic isolation on the divergence of pupfish populations has almost certainly been overestimated.-from Author

dc:title: Genetic differentiation within subdivided populations of Formica ants.
dc:creator: Pamilo P.
dc:description: Genetic subdivision was examined in island populations of Formica fusca and F. exsecta, and in continuous populations of F. sanguinea and F. transkaucasica. Estimates of genetic differentiation are based on the distribution of cMDH genotypes in the populations. Results suggest important microdifferentiation within Formica populations.-from Author

dc:title: Breeding system, genetic variability, and response to selection in Plectritis ( Valerianaceae).
dc:creator: Carey K.
dc:description: Plectritis congesta (c75% outcrossed in nature) and P. brachystemon (<2% outcrossed in nature) are very closely related species which occur sympatrically in a number of locations. Six generations of plants of both species were grown under controlled conditions, and separate populations selected for short and tall stature at anthesis, and for early and late anthesis. Despite breeding system differences, the 2 Plectritis species can maintain variability by similar processes (genetic) in some characters, as in flowering time, and by different processes (genetic in P. congesta, phenotypic in P. brachystemon) in other characters, as in height at anthesis.-from Author

dc:title: Density-dependent pollinator foraging, flowering phenology, and temporal pollen dispersal patterns in Linanthus bicolor.
dc:creator: Schmitt J.
dc:description: Addresses the following questions: 1) Within a Linanthus population, are there seasonal changes in rate and pattern of pollinator movements within or between plants? 2) Can the distribution of pollinator flight distances on a given date be predicted from flowering plant density? 3) Can differences between populations in the timing of flowering produce differences in the overall level of pollinator visitation through the season? 4) Can differences between populations in timing or shape of flowering phenology curves produce differences in overall potential for gene dispersal? -from Author

dc:title: Quantitative genetics of development, genetic correlations among age-specific trait values and the evolution of ontogeny.
dc:creator: Cheverud J.M.
dc:description: Genetic correlations among age-specific weights and tail lengths in a laboratory population of rats are presented. The effects of variable gene action on ontogenetic response to selection are demonstrated by a simulation of the correlated ontogenetic responses to selection at various ages. Phenotypic, maternal, and environmental correlation patterns were all similar to the genetic correlation pattern. The indices of integration are higher for maternal and genetic matrices than for the phenotypic and, especially, the environmental matrices. Ontogenetic stages are thus more closely linked in evolution than one would infer based on the phenotypic correlations alone. The patterns of genetic, phenotypic, maternal, and environmental correlation are similar for age- specific weights and tail lengths.-from Authors

dc:title: An estimate of the relative opportunities for natural and sexual selection in a population of milkweed beetles.
dc:creator: McCauley D.E.
dc:description: The two sexes were very similar with respect to the means and distributions of survivorship and mating success. Total fitness in males was defined as the product of the proportion of recaptures in which an individual was observed mating and the total amount of time (adult lifespan) available for mating. The opportunity for selection in this population of males was calculated from the distribution of fitnesses among individuals. The opportunity for selection was further broken down into natural selection due to variance in lifespan and sexual selection due to variance in the ability to acquire a mate during a short subset of total lifespan (mating efficiency). Variance in lifespan provides over 2 times more opportunity for selection than does variance in mating efficiency. -from Author

dc:title: Reproductive isolation in Sonoran Desert Drosophila.
dc:creator: Markow T.A.
dc:description: Four species of cactophilic Drosophila are endemic to the Sonoran Desert of North America. Populations of each species were collected from Baja California and from across the Gulf of Sonora on the mainland. Sexual isolation was only detected between mainland and peninsular populations of D. mojavensis. No assortative mating was observed among geographically isolated populations of the other species. Two of the species not showing isolation, D. nigrospiracula and D. mettleri, exhibit a host plant shift from Baja to Sonora while D. pachea does not. Drosophila mojavensis is the only species of the 4 which shows appreciable sympathy with its sibling species on the mainland; the observed behavioral isolation may have been most strongly influenced by this fact.-from Authors

dc:title: The heritability of external morphology in Darwin's ground finches ( Geospiza) on Isla Daphne Major, Galapagos.
dc:creator: Boag P.T.
dc:description: The repeatabilities of 7 external morphological characters were high for Geospiza fortis and G. scandens. Geospiza fortis mates displayed positive assortative mating with respect to morphology in 1976, but not 1978, while G. scandens showed no consistent assortative mating in any year. Heritabilities in G. fortis were high in both years, averaging .76 based on 3 types of parent-offspring regression and on full sib intraclass correlations. Heritabilities in G. scandens were lower, averaging .46. Genetic correlations were also high among the 7 characters in G. fortis, and had a multivariate structure like that seen in the phenotypic correlations. G. fortis morphological variation may be influenced by introgression with G. fuliginosa and frequency dependent, temporally fluctuating directional selection, while G. scandens morphology may reflect an evolutionary history predominated by stabilizing selection.-from Author

dc:title: A natural experiment in life-history evolution: field data on the introduction of mosquitofish ( Gambusia affinis) to Hawaii.
dc:creator: Stearns S.C.
dc:description: About 150 mosquitofish were introduced from Texas to Hawaii in 1905. Some 1367 pregnant females were collected in 1974 from 4 stable and 20 fluctuating reservoirs. Fish from stable reservoirs had fewer offspring, lower reproductive allocations, were thinner, shorter, and weighed less, than fish from fluctuating reservoirs. Length and condition explain 21-53% of variation of reproductive traits among stocks. The fluctuating reservoirs differ significantly in their fluctuation patterns, and these differences are reflected in the life-history traits of the fish living in them. Much of the variation among stocks was caused by plastic responses to short- term environmental changes. The pattern of variation in water levels in the more distant past (3-6 months) had strong effects on weight-adjusted fecundity than did the more recent past (1-3 months). The environment can induce significant lag effects in less than a generation via physiological plasticity. Water level fluctuations affect the expression of life-history traits in these stocks, but they cannot account for variation among the stocks from stable reservoirs. Founder effects may contribute to divergence among all stocks, and drift may contribute to divergence among fluctuating stocks.-from Author
